text:
So I think Reid doesn't
need any real introduction.

And you guys had a chance to
read a little bit about it. I'll just give a little
personal background. I was just thinking
like when we first met.

Do you remember when
we first met at Oxford? Yes. Yes. We were doing a
debate-- thankfully,

we were on the same team-- a debate about AI and
the future of work.

Yes. And we won it. We won that debate soundly. Yes, absolutely. It's probably online somewhere. And you can see us and a few
others debating that topic.

Reid's a cofounder, as you
know, of LinkedIn and a partner at Greylock, was at PayPal.

You guys have read some of
his stuff, Blitzscaling, and you just read a bit of
Impromptu, Startup of You.

And he was a cofounder
of Inflection AI-- we'll talk about that
in a little while--

and a board member at OpenAI
before moving over to Microsoft.

I was a board
member at Microsoft before I also joined
the OpenAI board. OK.

Did you did you stop
being a Microsoft board member for a while? No. You were the whole time. When they bought LinkedIn.

Yeah. Yeah. That's right. After [INAUDIBLE]. Right. Yeah, I remember I was with
you when that happened too.
Yes, exactly. We were at the Vatican and-- Places around the world.

[LAUGHTER] And Reid kept disappearing
and doing these phone calls. I was like, Reid,
that's kind of rude.

We're all here. And then I found out
that LinkedIn got sold. And I was like, OK, that's
a pretty good excuse.

So let me just start
off with a question. I think about gen AI.

So there's a bunch of
folks here in Gen Z, millennials, or whatever
generations you are.

And in your Bologna
commencement speech, you talked about this concept of
gen AI and how it's different.
Tell us a little bit about that. So,

macro thesis, which you've
seen in a number of things, is that actually one of the
things that is too often

not described of what's going
on with artificial intelligence is human amplification. So you can describe it as human
amplification intelligence.

And-- Is this microphone on? It should be. Yes. Maybe I need to just
move it a little closer.
That'll help. And speak up a bit. So,

the thesis is that if we're in a
cognitive industrial revolution

and the steam
engine of the mind, is it just an inevitable quick
thing to it's cognitively

better at us than
everything, or is there an extended period, maybe
a very, very long period

at which it's amplifying? And I think that's
underdescribed as a high probability. And so the various
work is various ways

of trying to show that. And it's anything
from showing how I would cowrite a book with AI.

I don't think I would do it
again that way or anyone else should, which is like,
prompt answer framing.

But as ways of showing what
it is as a research assistant. So what that leads
to is when you

begin to think about the
generations of human generations

or millennial and Gen X and
all the rest, to some degree,

those are correlating now more
with technological revolutions

and trends, familiarity
with the internet, familiarity with social media,
familiarity with mobile phones.

And that's what I actually take
in this human amplification thesis and also
have that as a posit

that one of the things
where I see optimism is that if you
think, hey, there's

actually going to be a
generation AI where people are natively using AI agents,
et cetera for how they navigate

their world and life,
that that actually is going to be a human
amplification set of moments. And that's one of the things
that we should be looking at.

And that's part
of the reason why I did that and was
kind of calling it generation AI to try to get
people to pay attention and--
Kind of a buzz word. Yes, exactly. But is it a whole generation? So I mean, when you--

as AI is advancing very rapidly
and we were talking about this a little bit earlier, and people
move down those scaling laws--

we'll talk more about that
in a little while I guess-- how long is that period where
humans and machines are working

together and that there's a-- is that something we
should be thinking of

is in decades, years, centuries? So my belief-- but I think
that intelligent people argue

everything from years
to centuries, right-- my belief is that it's more on
the decades, the centuries side,

in part because one
of the things that-- if you track what the trajectory
lines of the cognitive

capabilities of
these devices are-- And by the way, I
started my studies

in artificial intelligence while
I was an undergraduate here. This building didn't exist when
I was here as an undergraduate.

But Terman did, and I was
in Terman studying AI stuff. And what I actually
see is happening

is there's enormously
increasing set of cognitive capabilities
of doing certain kinds

of cognitive tasks. But I don't necessarily see
it doing one of the things that we say, well,
what is kind of

fundamental to human
intelligence is this kind of amalgam of you have
a context awareness that makes

you a very good adversarial
game player by which you change the rules of the game
in what you're doing.

you're going to die
unless you beat AlphaGo, you wouldn't try
to outplay it at Go

because you're
smart enough to know I'm going to lose if I do that. What you're going to
do is, can I unplug it?

Can I dump water on it? What are the other
kinds of things. And that's what I mean by
kind of adversarial game play.

And that kind of context
awareness and such of it, I think I haven't yet seen
enter into any of these scale

compute AI models
and how they operate.

And it's not to say
they couldn't certainly. And it's one of the things I'm--
there's a whole stack of things I measure for when we get
to the next level of scale.

Like what is recursive
self-improvement look like? And could it figure out how
to code the baseline learning

algorithm of how these things
work better than humans are coding them right now. I look at those kinds
of things to say,

are you having
some path to having some kind of massive
intelligence capability?

And the answer is, it's
superintelligence already today. GPT-4 is more capable at a bunch
of stuff than any one of us
in this room. But that's not alarming.

And so it's like, OK-- I tend to think that we will be
actually in the decades, maybe

even much longer
as collaborators by current heuristic guess.

But I update that guess every
time I look at a new system. Yeah. No, we're all updating
in real-time here.

But it is a really interesting
question that GPT-4, lots of tools already a lot
more intelligent than us

on some dimensions. And there's different
ways of being smart. I mean, obviously, whatever, a
chess computer or a calculator

can beat us. But even just you could
have a human or an AI that's

just faster than us even if it
does the same kind of reasoning or it can have some of
different kinds of knowledge.

But this tale of adversarial,
unusual approaches

is something that we seem
to have a real advantage in. Yeah. And also part of it
is we're adaptive.

And we go, OK, how do we
adapt to this new circumstance and with this new-- Outside the box.

Yes. Right, this new tool. So like, for example, I've
sat with CEOs who've said,

oh, maybe I should just
fire my marketing department and put GPT-4 in as my
marketing department.

And you're like, well,
think about the universe where everybody did that. Marketing is competitive.

It's how do you
market versus another. You're very quickly
going to hire back a marketing department. Maybe it'll be a
marketing department

knows how to use GPT-4. GPT-5 is playing a different
kind of marketing game using

this tool in order to do it. But that's part of
the reason why it's--
that's how we're iterating. And as I was pointing out-- I won't name these CEOs-- I was like, currently,

I have absolute confidence
that our planning capabilities for saying, hey, this is
going to be a 15-step plan.

Here's step one,
step two, step three. Wait a minute. Step three is a
little off my plan.

I'm now going to replan. I'm going to replan to
step three B and four prime

and so forth as
ways of doing this. Currently, these systems
aren't very good at doing that. They get trapped in all
kinds of lacuna and so forth.

That's getting better. That's not to say that it's
fixed to where it currently is. But that's, again, another
part of that kind of context

awareness of, are we on track? Do we need to pivot and iterate
in this competitive game?

And I think that's
one of the things that I have rational
optimism that we

will be adding into the
cognitive mix for quite some time. Yeah. It makes me think about-- so
when we did that call center

study, there was some questions
that came up very frequently. How do you change your password? There's this Pareto
curve with this long tail

of obscure questions that only
came up once in the data set. And the humans are really
good at those weird questions.

So that was a natural
division of labor. And I was thinking,
OK, the AI is kind of marching its way down. But I think what
you're making me

think is that that's not
a static set, that what's going to happen is the
system marches down,

humans will be thinking of all
these other ways around it. So that tail is just going to
keep growing for quite a while.

Like maybe at some point, the AI
will get better at doing those one-off, weird,
out-of-the-box cases.

But for a long time,
the humans seem to have a comparative
advantage in figuring out how to go down that far end.

Is that kind of what-- Yes, exactly. For example, one of the things
is-- like, obviously, I'm a massive believer in the value
of creating autonomous vehicles.

I think it's good for humanity
in all kinds of different ways. But like, for example, one thing
that we haven't fitness-tested

these autonomous
vehicles yet on is what happens when you have
human beings trying to defeat the autonomous vehicles?

And the answer is, we
can do it pretty easily. Yeah, they start bullying it. And they found
that a little bit.

You come to an intersection. And you know that the autonomous
vehicle is going to give way. It's been programmed that way.

And you can start--
people started doing that. And human beings are
very good at doing that. It doesn't require
an elite degree.

So it's related to another
concept, cognitive GPS. How is this similar or different
there, the generation AI?

So you're using this tool,
but with a cognitive GPS, you're kind of relying on it for
a lot of the decision-making.

So part of the reason I use the
GPS as a metaphor for this--

and this is part
of-- it's going to be a chapter in a book that I'll
be publishing in, I think, early next year.

And part of it is to both
show all of the good things,

but also show some of the
challenges and course of it. So you say, well, look at what
GPS is added to our lives.

It means that we now can go to
unusual new places very easily. We can go, OK, where is a good
place to have lunch nearby?

We can find out that our friends
are actually here in town

and say, hey, let's
grab a coffee. There's all kinds of things that
lead to the kind of navigation of the world.

And if you say this
is a steam engine mind and it's kind of navigation of
a variety of cognitive tasks and mental tasks, you
have all of that kind

of navigational enablement. On the other hand, GPS is
not without its questions.

Like, for example, we all
voluntarily carry around our LoJack trackers.

And the kinds of things
that come about because of those LoJack trackers can
be unpleasant and unsurprising

ways, and not just in
circumstances of war

when Russian general
is carrying one around. But there's a number of
things that can happen there.

And it raises questions
about privacy, raises questions around-- What about the cognitive
things-- so one of the things

I find when I use the GPS is
my brain just-- sometimes, I used to disagree with it. Now I don't bother.

If it says to go this
way, I almost always just follow the instructions. Fine for driving. It's not like the most
important decision.

But if you have a GPS for
all your other decisions, how do I reply to my wife?
Which job offer should I take?

If you start delegating more
and more of the decisions, I mean, what does
that do to our--

That's precisely the thing
about where you have to be. You have to navigate
and say, well,

look, some of these previous
areas of intelligence that were highly valued
become less valued.

That's already
happened in history. So for example,
centuries ago, memory used to be the most
important high order bit.

And now, memory is
important because you have to have enough working
memory to figure out how do I go find this information.

But if you go, well, I
don't really remember that. I can find it. It doesn't matter as much.

So there's changing nature. Then there's this
question around, well, like don't allow yourself to
get intellectually sloppy.

And for example,
we already see that on a bunch of stuff
on the internet. I found this on the internet. It must be true. You're like, well, I
hate to break it to you.

And so similarly,
the question will be as it produces more
and more valuable,

reliable navigational
advice, you'll tend to say, well, that's
just the thing I should do. And that will be a challenge, is
overreliance will be a challenge

that we'll have to navigate. I mean, can you imagine. Is this a net bad
thing, a net good thing

if people start delegating
a lot of their decisions to an AI for them. Does that free them up to
spend the remaining brainpower

on more important things? Or do they become like robots? Well, I think the
important thing-- and this is part of
why the dialogue is

important-- the important
thing is, what's the way that we should
be training these agents so that they're helping human
beings get to their better

lives, their better selves? And some of that is,
by the way, no, no, no, don't read that crazy theory
on the internet about how

[? hydrochloroquine ?]
is good for your COVID. Well, OK, but you're having
the AI tell them that?

Possibly, yes. Look, this is the
governance of these-- Is this kind of circular? I mean, you're telling
them to listen to a machine
to tell them what to read? That's even scarier. Well, we do that already.

Well, just because look,
there's these search engines that produce-- like I'm
searching for a query

and I'm looking for something. Look, I'm imagining
oversimplify to one where we are very trusting
in our technological sources

and do what they tell us to do. And the other is where we
don't have those crutches.

Maybe we make worse decisions,
but we're deciding ourselves. And I'm saying, is it
obvious that the one

where the AI system is giving
us these better answers? You're imagining that the AI
system is telling us not to.

Was it hydrochloric? Hydrochloric, yeah. Whatever the thing that Trump
was pumping as a COVID solution.

Will somebody who likes
Trump be using an AI system

that tells them to do that? Well but actually, I think this
is part of what we get to is, what is the formulation-- what
is the range of these AI agents?

Where should be the range of
choice by individuals doing it? Yeah. What should be the-- But in either world--

Well, but by example. --now you're putting more
power in Inflection AI to tell me what to do.

Well, I think that
the short answer is that we always presume on
some things outside ourselves.

The Robinson Crusoe--
this may be news to you-- is a myth, right? We live in a social
environment--

We totally do. --which we are-- And maybe people have
always been following somebody's instructions.

We are. That's the short answer. And is that not
changing over time. Well, it changes, but we should
try to change it for the better.

So, for example,
if you say, look, the artifact that I
have now-- for example, one of the major artifacts that
we used for centuries was books.

And which books
should you trust? And which one should
you read on this? And which books you do say,
that book, that's now wrong.

OK. Ether Theory of Physics,
that's now wrong. Don't read the Ether Theory
of Physics book on relativity.

So let me take a different
dystopian aspect to it.

If these AI systems,
because of scaling laws, become more and
more centralized, we were talking
earlier that it could

be a relatively small number of
them is that-- so now there's a relatively small
number of everyone

following a certain
set of instructions. Is that worse than
having a disorganized set

of tens of thousands or
hundreds of thousands of books and articles? Well, I think what
you want is you

want the right blend of
trust sometimes and innovate and differentiate
in other times.

And that was the reason I was
going to a medical example, because if you said,
hey, my theory is--

take one of the classic,
I think, idiots things of our time, which is the
anti-vax people, which

is, I know someone who
had a bad side effect. And vaccines can be bad for you.

And you're like, look,
dude, the statistic bath. Of course, there are
some people where--

but all of us as a group are
much better off with the lottery when we all take the vaccine.

And the negative outcomes for
most children, most adults

are much, much better
when we're all doing it. But it's just like the--

Singapore has a centralized
system of government that works great when they've
got a benevolent dictator.

But if a different
person became in power, it would be really, really bad. Couldn't the same
thing happen if we

had this oracle that
under your vision is telling us the correct
medical knowledge. But if somehow that
oracle went bad,

then we'd all get
the wrong knowledge. Is that riskier? Well, I think it's one of
the reasons why you always have a kind of a
plural diversity

and part of the
cross-checking it like you do with medical
knowledge is you have multiple sources
cross-checking it.

You have-- So there's not a single oracle. And also, look, I
actually think part of this agenda
universe we're isn't

going to be like the one
ring of the one model. I think it will be multiple
models composed together

in cross-checking. Like, for example part of how
you get safety in alignment is say, oh, you're asking for
something that may be self-harm.

So the. There will be a model
that will specialize in trying to figure
out, are you trying

to figure out how to have the
agent age you in your self harm?

And it's going to say,
whoa, whoa, whoa, nope. Nope. No, don't answer that
question that way. Because we have a
tremendous number of people

die through suicides. Let's try to
diminish that number. Let's try to alleviate the
kind of mental suffering

rather than create the
suicide enablement model.

But who's making that
decision about that? It sounds like the way
you're describing it,

there's a team at
OpenAI or Inflection that says we don't
want that to happen.

Well, there's definitely
teams that are doing that. There's definitely
the teams are talking to each other and publishing
papers and doing all that.

There's definitely discussions
with both the government on what are the kinds of things
that create alignment on safety?

And there's discussions with the
press when the press is being critical about why
it is you're trying to be a good steward
for these things.

And that has to be
a range of things. And so networks
of accountability really need to be there. And part of those-- and
those networks are all them.

Like one of the things that
the press dialogue tends to be misinformed on is they
go, well, companies only

really care about their profit. It's like, well, no, companies
care about their equity value over time, which can be
really crushed if they

do something really bad. And if you get called
in front of Congress or other kinds of things,
those can be bad and things.

And so they're trying to
create their equity value at the time, which is
broadly their networks

of responsibility. It doesn't mean trust
them on everything. There have been
cigarette companies. One more question on
this plurality versus--

and then I promise
we'll move on. I'm fine. [LAUGHS] Kai-Fu Lee
was saying that he

thought that every country
should have separate LLMs. There shouldn't be just
a few Bay Area companies

that decide what the truth is. Do you think it
would be a good idea if we had hundreds
of different LLMs,

each with their own local morals
and understandings of medicine?

Well, I think a diversity
of LLMs is good. And even when you
get the medicine, you could say,
well, wait a minute,

this acupuncture LLM is
actually surprisingly good when you look at
the medical data.

And we should compare
and contrast its results with Western medicine. And when Western medicine has
done analysis of acupuncture,

they don't really
understand what the cause. But they say, look,
there's actually in these deeply controlled
studied groups that

had some positive effects. And so you'd want to have
that kind of diversity both for the now and ongoing
because knowledge, learning,

and truth is a dynamic process. It's like science. We get better and
better at it, and we want to make sure
we have the openness

to the diversity of that. And I think that's also a value
in the diversity of broadly

different ethical systems. Now, I want the ethical systems
that view kind of nonviolence

as a human societal
goal, both within society

and between societies. I want those to have more force
because I think that's a better

world to be living in. And I think the
ethical systems which embody that are better
ethical systems.

I think the ethical
systems that allow as much individual
autonomy as you can

without creating violence to
other human beings, I think, is also a good thing.

But specifically that
question, would the world be better if France, Brazil,
Saudi Arabia, China each

had their own system
and didn't use OpenAIs and Gemini and Inflection?

Or do you think that the
world is better if we pool our resources into a few--

Well, there's definitely
some value in pooling, but I actually think that
the notion of having-- it's one of the reasons--

the parallel is, I
try to help stand up entrepreneurial ecosystem in
every kind of Western style

democracy. So I will meet with any
government leader on, can we create a Silicon Valley
in Singapore, France, Germany,

UK, et cetera? Brazil, sure. I haven't had that meeting yet,
but I would do that meeting.

But I also view the
Western style democracies, I want that to be the style
where the world governance is

heading towards. And that doesn't mean that
we have it exactly right here or the French have
it exactly right.

But it's like I want to be
on that journey and path. So, for example, all the ones
you mentioned seem to be fine.

If you said today, would I
want to have a Russian LLM? The answer is no.

OK. Fair enough. I'm going to go to the students. I got one more question. So a few weeks ago, I
read that Mustafa Suleyman

was leaving Inflection
and going to Microsoft. And I was like pretty
stunned, actually,

because I knew you had
put a lot of money in. I was like, he's screwing Reid. This is not good. [LAUGHTER]

So I sent you a quick text,
and you responded right back and said-- it was
like a smiley face. It wasn't a smiley face.
It was a-- what was it? The usual one I do with. Yeah, it's the glasses emoji--

smiley face. That's my normal. That's the normal response. I got the sense you
were you were not upset.
Yeah. Tell us what really happened.

That question, I'm not
sure I'm answering exactly. Try it. Yes. Look, so part of what
we're doing with Inflection

was to say, it's a
public benefit corp. And part of the thing is
the mission is, how do we--

because for example, to
your very earliest question, what's the notion
of designing agents that would help maybe
everybody but a lot of people

be their better
versions of their self? And so for example, on the
Inflection and Pi side,

it's like if you go to Pi and
say, you're my best friend, Pi won't go, I'm
your best friend.

You should spend all
your time with me. Because it will
go, well, that's-- That's unhealthy. That's unhealthy. It's just like, no, no, no.

I'm here as your companion. But I'm here to help you
with the other friends.

Let's talk about some
of your other friends. Have you talked to
other friends recently? They're out of town. It's like, OK, well, when
are you going to see them?

How many of you
guys have used Pi? You guys [INAUDIBLE]. Yeah, I recommend
it, but whatever. Yeah. It's fun.

It is very friendly. I would say it's my best friend.  But part of our
training of it is

to not try to absorb your
attention to Pi, but to help you

be your better self
navigating the world. And that's, for example,
when you say, well,

what kinds of AI
agents should we have? We should have AI agents
like PI and other ones.

Like when you're navigating
these the various kind of cognitive GPS.

Isn't it bad for Inflection
when Mustafa leaves? Well, so what we were--

And not just him, the
chief science officer. So the theory for us
was, this is our mission.

Would it be best to create
an agent in Inflection? And what we realized
when we looked

at where the nature of
doing these agents was and what the economic
business models of them

would be over time, that
the business at Inflection should pivot.

And we pivoted it
towards a developer API for more kind of B2B
kind of economics.

But then we said, well, but
we care about public benefit corp. We care about
this mission intensely.

Maybe there's a way to have
that mission keep going. And the thought was-- You didn't have enough scale.

We didn't think that the startup
path for that would work. Even with all the money,
billion, whatever.

Well, we thought it
would take billions. And then capital markets,
revenue streams, et cetera.

Whereas the business opportunity
for Inflection was around--

was how do you
create-- because we have a unique API
with this stuff because we're the only of these
models that actually explicitly
trains EQ equally with IQ. Right. No. Right. So it's a unique model. It's EQ easier than IQ?

It's same. It's different, but same kind
of human feedback reinforcement and so forth. But you have to do
the same kind of--

Definitely has a higher EQ. Yes. Definitely. And so the goal with Inflection
was high IQ, high EQ.

And we said, OK, we'll
provide that on a B2B model because that's where the actual
business of this is going. And then Mustafa and
Karen were like, well,

we want to keep doing the agent. Maybe we can work out this deal
with Microsoft where both wins.

And to be clear about billions,
is that because of scaling laws or is it broader
economics than that?

Is it like the classic working
down the compute data parameters

all have to grow or is
it something-- or are there aspects of scale? It's fundamentally--
well, this is the reason

why the AI revolution is
a scale compute revolution and is fundamentally commercial.

Is it scale compute,
scale data, scale teams, taking risks doing it.

And companies are the only
things that outside of wartime can do that. But I mean, when I say scaling--

I mean, like the
very specifically like the Dario Amodei
Chinchilla type, is that the one that
you're specifically or is--

it sounds like it's
broader than that. Well, I think it'll be scale
across all of these vectors, which includes scale compute.

But I was saying
it's more than that. That and. All right.

So these guys write these
great assignments here. We are really smart group here. So I want to call
out a few of them.
There's so many good ones. But is-- Here? We just want to do that.

OK. You can come back to her. Yes. How about-- so you want
to tell us about your--

so Reid loves to
think about futures where things can go right. He's a Star Trek fan.

Tell us about your-- When we launched Stanford
Human-Centered AI Institute, the post
that I did was,
what could possibly go right? I remember that. Exactly. So not what could go wrong? What could go right?
So tell us what could go right. Whoa. [LAUGHTER]

Sorry. I didn't tell you I
was going to call. Should we pass her a mic. Yeah. You want a mic? What could go right in gaming?
Well, gaming and-- I don't know. If you want. You don't have to.

On your assignment. Eric, I didn't know you
were a brutal cold caller. I'm a cold caller. I learned that
early in teaching.

Yes. So I worked at a gaming
company two summers ago,

and I'm a co-chairman AI. And the assignment was
just thinking about ways that a certain industry
could benefit from AI.

So I first talked about how-- I think like a
common application in the beginning of
generative AI was with NPCs,

like language models have it
more interactive and immersive. But I also think that
we can also have it--

I mostly focus on
a systems aspect. So how do we use generative AI
and coding in system development

as we look from less of
macro computer science, like individual devs to also
seeing how these generative AI

systems with more
